Award.AwardTitle: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Theory-Enabled Development of 2D Metal Dichalcogenides as Active Elements of On-Chip Silicon-Integrated Optical Communication

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Development of Materials for On-Chip Silicon-Integrated Optical Communication


Data transfer rates between silicon electronic chips are reaching a limit that prevents the continued development of high speed smart-phones, computers, and internet devices. While silicon?s properties are excellent for electronic devices, optical sources based on silicon are incapable of efficient, high-speed communication. Within the framework of the Materials Genome Initiative, this project will seek new materials and associated fabrication processes to overcome this hurdle. Recently it has been shown that MDC materials, such as molybdenum disulfide, can be grown in large-scale, high quality, atomically thin films on silicon dioxide substrates. Theoretically, it is predicted that such materials are semiconductors with a tunable, direct band gap that renders them far superior for optical communication applications than silicon. This research project intends to develop a theory-driven understanding of fabrication and control of such atomically-thin materials towards validating their use as on-chip light sources for future optical interconnects for integrated circuits. The PIs have an excellent track of record on promoting STEM activities within their respective institution. They intend to work with high school students, undergraduate and graduate students, and involve students from underrepresented groups in the planned research. The outreach activities proposed in this project are solid and will definitely have a broader societal impact.

The goals of this project are to create a continuous knowledge link between atomistic material theory and chemical material synthesis of a variety of 2D metal dichalcogenidies and their alloys as a foundation for discovering, synthesizing, and accelerating the next generation of on-chip laser devices suitable for applications in telecommunication and data-processing. It builds on recent findings by the principal investigators such as strain-stabilization of different metal
dichalcogenide phases, mm-scale growth of continuous single-layer molybdenum disulfide films, and loss management and demonstration of laser devices featuring optical mode sizes below the diffraction limit of light. The research collaborators will combine theoretical screening of a broad range of materials and predictive modeling of substrate stabilization of their structure, with development of growth methods for a diverse set of materials, and application-near functional evaluation on a waveguide tested. This project brings together an interdisciplinary set of methods ranging from analytical and numerical simulation, to chemical process development and the design and characterization of on-chip integrated laser devices. This vertical, theory-based integration of materials development methods realizes the goal of the Materials Genome Initiative. Success of this project will provide input to the field of functional 2D materials for years to come that will be instrumental in the development of novel photonic integrated circuits, and potentially sensors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award funded collaborative research between the research groups of Evan Reed at the Materials Science & Engineering Department of Stanford University, Volker Sorger at the Electrical Engineering Department of George Washington University and Ludwig Bartels at the Chemistry Department of the University of California, Riverside. This report addressed the outcomes specific to Bartels’ Research group. In addition to tangible research results, this project afforded undergraduate and graduate students of Bartels’ research group the opportunity to interact with premier research universities. The University of California, Riverside, is one of very few Research Institutions that have an enrollment of > 1/3 Hispanic students: the majority of Bartels graduate and undergraduate students identify as Hispanic. In the course of the project, Bartels and a score of his undergraduate and students vanpooled to Stanford multiple times, introducing them to research there. Several students of Bartels also traveled to George Washington University.

Research results were obtained in two directions: a) computationally guided single-layer material synthesis and b) testbeds for single-layer material characterization:

a) Materials that have defined properties at the single-layer limit have attracted a lot of attention over the past decades because they may be understood as the ultimate step in miniaturization of functional materials. For instance, as the semiconductor industry progresses towards larger and larger number of transistors per chip, each smaller than in previous generations, materials are needed that have well defined properties even when thinned to the current characteristic sizes of transistors of just a few nanometers. Going into this project, the Bartels lab had experience in the deposition of single-layer materials such as molybdenum disulfide and its alloys, but only the thermodynamically most stable phase could be prepared. Computational guidance by project leader Reed of Stanford suggested that specific process gases can render other phases stable under growth conditions – so that rapid quenching from growth conditions can offer practical access to these materials. In particular, Reed’s group screened a large number of process gas additives and found that carbon dioxide can stabilize a semi-metallic phase of molybdenum ditelluride, although the thermodynamically stable phase under ambient condition is semiconducting. Utilizing this guidance, the Bartels group was able to develop a process that not only allows access to either of the phases mentioned but also an intermediary metallic one. This project showed how a single material can be prepared a single layer thick as metallic, semi-metallic or semiconducting depending on the growth process. More generally, it showed that when a material is a single layer thin only, the process gas composition can easily have a phase determining impact because the surface to volume ration in a single-layer material is very large – and that this impact can be predicted using current computational tools.

Ib) n most cases, the interaction between light and material is relatively weak; as a consequence, optical probing of single-layer materials is subject to practical limitations of miniscule interaction volume. In this project, the collaborators designed antenna structures that can be lithographically fabricated on top of a single-layer material, so that the antenna amplify the electrical field of the optical probe exactly at the single-layer material under investigation. This enhancement results in stronger light-matter interaction and better signal-to-noise in the optical characterization of the material under investigation. This project realized this approach by means of fabricating optical antenna on single layer tungsten disulfide prepared by students of the Bartels group.  Under the influence of the antenna, the material exhibited brighter photoluminescence and enhanced Raman response.
